Award.AwardTitle: Conference on Graph Decompositions at Michigan Technological University
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funds to support expenses for participants of the 4th Annual Kliakhandler Conference on Graph Decompositions, which will be held on August 9-11, 2018 on the campus of Michigan Technological University. The purpose of this conference is to stimulate research activity and collaboration between members of the mathematical sciences community. The conference is focused in the area of graph decompositions. Graph decomposition problems regularly appear in the fields of graph theory, design theory, and algebra and have applications to communication, optimization, and algorithms.

The conference will also include a special session titled "Everyday Combinatorics", which will focus on combinatorics at the high school level. A combinatorics specialist with an interest in math education will organize the session, and local high school teachers will be invited to attend. The website address for the conference is http://kliak.mtu.edu/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 4th Kliakhandler Conference was held August 9-11, 2018 on the campus of Michigan Technological University in Houghton, MI.  The Kliakhandler Conference is an annual event held on the campus of Michigan Technological University in Houghton, Michigan. It was funded by a generous gift from Igor Kliakhandler, with additional support from the National Science Foundation. Each year proposals are submitted by MTU faculty and the winner selects a theme for the annual conference. This year the theme was Graph Decompositions and their Applications. Invited speakers were Brian Alspach from University of Newcastle, Australia, Saad El-Zanati from Illinois State University, Chris Rodger from Auburn University, and Tommaso Traetta from University of Padova, Italy.

The conference consisted of research talks given by the invited speakers, who are experts in the area of graph decompositions and contributed talks given by junior and senior faculty and graduate students who work on graph decompositions and their applications.  The talks gave researchers the opportunity to present their work to an audience that is interested in their field of study and also learn from other experts. Both groups benefitted from interacting with eachother, collaborations were formed, and new research projects were stimulated by some of the reserach talks.

A special session entitled “Everyday Combinatorics” was held, in which participants learned about ways to incorporate graph decompositions in their classrooms. The special session featured Jane Butterfield from University of Victoria, David Clark from Grand Valley State University, and Daniel Schultheis from Smith College. The session provided a way for high school math teachers and university professors to meet and learn from eachother.  Participants enjoyed a hands-on session that included many fun and interesting activities that they could bring back to their classrooms.
